title: Rift Deepens Between Michael Flynn, Prosecutors Over Cooperation
text:
WASHINGTON—Former national security adviser Michael Flynn ’s new legal team accused the government of withholding critical evidence in his criminal case, and prosecutors hinted on Tuesday that they might depart from their earlier recommendation that Mr. Flynn get no prison time.

U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan set a tentative date of Dec. 18 for Mr. Flynn’s sentencing, though his legal team objected and pressed for more time.

Mr. Flynn’s lawyer, Sidney Powell, said there was evidence of “egregious government misconduct” during the investigation of Mr. Flynn, who pleaded guilty in 2017 to lying to investigators during his brief tenure at the White House about his interactions with the Russian ambassador before President Trump’s inauguration. Ms. Powell said the government wasn’t meeting its obligations to provide information and evidence that could exonerate her client.

“There never would have been a plea to begin with if the government had met its Brady obligation,” Ms. Powell said, referring to a disclosure requirement named for the 1963 Supreme Court case Brady v. Maryland.

Ms. Powell said the government possesses evidence that would have exonerated Mr. Flynn, though much of it was unrelated to the central facts at issue in Mr. Flynn’s guilty plea.

In her arguments before Judge Sullivan, Ms. Powell—a strident legal commentator and longtime critic of the investigation by former special counsel Robert Mueller —echoed many allegations by Mr. Trump and his allies, including that investigators were biased and that Mr. Flynn was the victim of a hostile FBI. The government disputed Ms. Powell’s account and says it has provided everything it is obligated to.

Mr. Flynn was an early cooperating witness in the Mueller probe, which concluded that Russian interference in the 2016 election was “sweeping and systematic” but didn’t identify evidence of coordination between Moscow and the Trump campaign. The former U.S. Army lieutenant general sat for more than a dozen interviews with investigators and provided “substantial assistance” to the special counsel team, according to prosecutors who later recommended Mr. Flynn receive a lenient sentence, including the possibility of no jail time.

“His early cooperation was particularly valuable because he was one of the few people with long-term and firsthand insight regarding events and issues under investigation,” prosecutors said in a brief last year about his sentencing.

But in court on Tuesday, prosecutors hinted that deal may now be in jeopardy. When Judge Sullivan asked Justice Department official Brandon Van Grack if the government still stood by its recommendation that Mr. Flynn get no jail time, he declined to answer, saying that it would address the issue in a future court filing.

The relationship between the government and its star cooperating witness began to unravel earlier this year when Mr. Flynn fired his longtime lawyers at the firm Covington & Burling and retained Ms. Powell.

Prosecutors had planned to call Mr. Flynn in the trial of a business associate that began in July. But at the last minute, they decided not to use him as a witness and suggested in court filings they didn’t believe he would tell the truth on the witness stand.

Since then, Ms. Powell has questioned the circumstances surrounding Mr. Flynn’s guilty plea and asked the judge to sanction the government for “malevolent conduct” in its investigation of him.

She has stopped short of asking the judge for permission to withdraw Mr. Flynn’s guilty plea.

Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.com
description: Former national security adviser Michael Flynn’s legal team accused the government of withholding evidence, and prosecutors hinted they might depart from their recommendation that he get no jail time.
